text: The Genesis of a Theocratic Republic

The Islamic Revolution of 1979 transformed Iran from a secular monarchy under Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi into a theocratic republic unlike any other modern state. Led by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, a Shia cleric who had spent fifteen years in exile, the revolution combined religious fervor with anti-imperialist nationalism.

caption: Khomeini arrives at Tehran airport, February 1, 1979

text: Velayat-e Faqih: Guardianship of the Jurist

At the heart of Iran's new political order was the concept of velayat-e faqih, or guardianship of the Islamic jurist. This doctrine, developed by Khomeini during his exile, held that in the absence of the Hidden Imam—a messianic figure in Shia Islam—a qualified Islamic jurist should serve as supreme political and religious leader.
This was a revolutionary reinterpretation of Shia theology, which had traditionally kept clerics separate from direct political rule.

The Iran-Iraq War, which began in September 1980 when Saddam Hussein invaded Iran, profoundly shaped the Islamic Republic's early development. The war lasted eight years and cost hundreds of thousands of lives.

text: The hostage crisis that began on November 4, 1979, when Iranian students seized the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, destroyed any hope for a moderate approach. The students held 52 American diplomats hostage for 444 days.
Rather than condemn the action, Khomeini endorsed it, recognizing its utility for radicalizing the revolution and breaking ties with the United States.

By 1981, the theocratic republic's basic structure was firmly in place. The system combined elements of democracy and dictatorship, republic and theocracy, in a way that defied conventional political categories. This hybrid system, born from revolution and war, would prove remarkably resilient even as it generated chronic instability and popular discontent.
